The Noob Approach: Ruby On Rails Part 1

August 13, 2013

Is this post for you ?

This blog assumes that you have basic knowledge of the following web technologies:

  • CSS
  • HTML
  • Javascript
  • Competent with terminal
  • Git

So you have decided to get started with Ruby on Rails? Much easier said than done. I remember when I thought that and thought it would take a week or so, but I found it very difficult and time consuming as it felt like I had a major lack of direction when trying to break into the world of Ruby on Rails. I hope this post can shed a little light from my past experiences and get you on the right track.

If you are not familiar with web technologies such as PHP or django you may have some difficulty wrapping your head around the idea of dynamic web applications

Getting Started with Installation

For Winodws users please check out railsinstaller.org

For Mac users I highly suggest you read the railscasts guide

One of the most daunting tasks for getting started with Rails may be the fact that installing it can be quite a bitch. So, for you linux users I have supplied a list of command to enter into your terminal. Note: you will need sudo powa

What installs?
  • RVM [Ruby Version Manager]
  • Ruby 1.9.3
  • Rails 3
  • nodejs
  • git (sign up for an account if you already haven't!)
  • sqlite
  • cURL
If you wish to use more modern versions of software you must edit the command line snippets yourself. Enter these commands into your terminal in numerical order
  1. sudo apt-get install -y curl #installing cURL a maic
  2. curl -L get.rvm.io | bash -s stable
  3. echo [[ -s "$HOME/.rvm/scripts/rvm" ]] && source "$HOME/.rvm/scripts/rvm" >> ~/.bash_profile
  4. sudo apt-get install git sqlite
  5. echo | sudo apt-add-repository ppa:chris-lea/node.js
    sudo apt-get update
    sudo apt-get install -y nodejs
  6. rvm install 1.9.3
  7. source ~/.rvm/scripts/rvm
  8. rvm use 1.9.3 --default
  9. gem install rails

Easy right? Well was not for me when getting start, I hope this can shine a little light. If you have issues please leave a comment and I will try to help to the best of my knowledge

After all is installed lets try a few terminal ccode-ommands to check if everything is actually there (Note: Output may vary)

$nodejs

Now let's create a test application make sure everything "clicks"

Terminal

Rails is generating what is calleld the scaffolding, the frame work of the rails project

To visit the homepage of the freshly created app we will need the terminal, by default rails uses port 3000 for local development

That wraps it up for installation
